awd_titl_txt: Cyber-Physical Systems Security through Robust Adaptive Possibilitistic Algorithms: a Cross Layered Framework
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of this project is to develop a cross-layer cyber-physical security framework for the smart grid. The proposed research will improve the quality of real-time monitoring of the smart grid through anomaly analysis. This will lead to more reliable data for control, situation awareness to first responders and other improved applications to smart grids. The proposed research will improve the resilience of smart grids to cyber-attacks in meters, parameters, topology and communication infrastructure and large physical disturbances by developing new techniques for distributed control of large complex systems that guarantees secure and reliable performance. The project will foster education through enhancement to curriculum by building bridges among communications, machine learning, power and control systems. The PIs plan to teach short courses on smart grid security at conferences.  In addition, they plan to engage under-represented minority students in their project. 

The project aims at developing a distributed nonlinear controller for transient stability enhancement. The new control layer will actuate on distributed energy storage systems, be robust to uncertainties in modelling and capable of compensating input time-delay while independent of operating conditions. Furthermore, the robust controller will not require exact knowledge of the system dynamics. Second, bad data analytics based on the innovation approach and cross-layered information provided by distributed software-defined network will be developed. The bad data analytics will consider the inherent interdependencies of the physical processes while providing a countermeasure. Third, an adaptive distributed robust machine learning approach will be developed. The overwhelming majority of supervised machine learning methods require large amounts of carefully labeled training data that is representative of the data distribution to be seen under test. However, in security applications, novel threats and malicious attacks are continuously being developed and attempted. Thus, approaches that rely on prior training data are unlikely to be robust in the case of behaviors never seen before, as would be the case in a rapidly changing threat environment. The novel distributed machine intelligence method that will be developed will be focused on being rapidly adaptive to identifying and distinguishing novel threats given even only one example of an anomalous novel threat.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The ultimate goal of this project was to help the power grid to become more reliable to cyber-physical threats and to enhance system robustness to contingencies. Towards such, we have developed  a cross-layer cyber-physical security framework, composed by physical and cyber domains. The cyber domain is composed by analysis and management layers. The physical layer represents the low-level applications such as data-collection and existing control and protection systems. On the cyber domain, high-level functions take the input from data acquired at the physical layer and implement distributed state estimation, robust control and machine intelligence (DMI) actions that require interactions between the subsystems on the physical layer. The model structure is presented in Fig. 1. 

The top layer is the management layer where a Distributed Software-Defined Network (D-SDN) leverages data and statistics from communications and machine intelligence to detect abnormal behavior of the communication network and prompt the analysis layer to take corrective actions. From the perspective of power systems control, we envision enhancing stability through a multi-agent approach, which features distributed cooperative agents that enable the cross-layer interaction between the three layers in real time. 

Fig. 2 presents an expanded view of the agents. Each agent is composed of a DESS, a Synchronous Generator (SG), a Robust Adaptive Possibilistic (RAP) controller with SDN access, a Phasor Measurement Unit (PMU) and a Distributed State Estimator (DSE). We advocate that DESS should be used for the enhancement of transient stability margins. Fast acting DESS can provide an important power source at emergency conditions, which help leverage the increasing deployment of low-inertia power generation.

The controller on each control agent uses distributed nonlinear techniques, which can handle time delays in communication as well as uncertainties in plant parameters and disturbances. We believe it is necessary to use a nonlinear controller because the large disturbances that create instability can shift the point of operation of the power system, which can harm the performance of linear controllers that are designed for specific operating conditions. The output of each distributed controller modulate the power output of grid-connected DESS to stabilize rotor angle oscillations. The DESS are comprised of fast-acting storage devices, such as batteries and flywheels, which can absorb or inject power into the local bus under the command of the control signal. The rationale behind this approach is that power from DESS can be used to balance swing equations and drive associated rotor speed towards stability. Fig. 3 presents the overall data flow of the proposed cross-layer smart grid security framework.

Distributed Machine Intelligence algorithms run on every PMU. These algorithms analyze PMU communication data flow statistics and content of the packets, and query DSE for additional information as needed. The result of this analysis is reported to the SDN, which will receive the input from DMI and actuate on the communication network while reporting relevant information. In regards to cyber-physical security, differently from previous approaches that propose smart grids (SG) cyber-physical security considering the system as one and present security solutions for the entire system, this project obtained enhanced cyber-physical security by manipulating the characteristics and security specifications of each layer in a cross layered model to provide specific integrated counter measures to deal with cyber-physical threats.

In regards to enhance system robustness to contingencies, instead on relying on the inertia of synchronous generators (SG) and exact model knowledge, as previous approaches which propose transient stability enhancement, this project developed a distributed nonlinear controller actuating on distributed energy storage systems (DESS), such as flywheels and grid connected batteries, robust to uncertainties in modeling and capable of compensating input time-delay while independent of operating conditions. Tests on a hardware-in-the-loop in scale conditions were implemented. Fig 4. illustrates the testbed developed. Major findings of this project include.

1) A distributed nonlinear controller for transient stability enhancement is obtained and can be easily implemented. The distributed nonlinear controller developed considers DESS as well as photo voltaic energy resources (PV), is robust to unknown time-varying delay, uncertainties on measurements as well as considers limited resource capacities.

2) Bad data analytics based on the innovation approach and D-SDN information are capable to provide enhanced security to power grid operation. The bad data analytics developed is able to detect several different simultaneous cybersecurity threats. These include: false data injection (FDI) attacks; denial-of-services attacks; man-in-the middle attacks; and system parameter attacks.

3) Adaptive distributed robust machine learning approach can provide temporal knowledge to quasi-static state estimators. The distributed machine learning solution has adaptive statistics, which enables real-time environment features learning while leveraging physics-based models information.
